review.title: Automated Fabric Defect Inspection: A Survey of Classifiers
review.abstract: Quality control at each stage of production in textile industry has become a key factor to retaining the existence in the highly competitive global market. Problems of manual fabric defect inspection are lack of accuracy and high time consumption, where early and accurate fabric defect detection is a significant phase of quality control. Computer vision based, i.e. automated fabric defect inspection systems are thought by many researchers of different countries to be very useful to resolve these problems. There are two major challenges to be resolved to attain a successful automated fabric defect inspection system. They are defect detection and defect classification. In this work, we discuss different techniques used for automated fabric defect classification, then show a survey of classifiers used in automated fabric defect inspection systems, and finally, compare these classifiers by using performance metrics. This work is expected to be very useful for the researchers in the area of automated fabric defect inspection to understand and evaluate the many potential options in this field.

metadata.title: AUTOMATED FABRIC DEFECT INSPECTION: A SURVEY OF CLASSIFIERS

sections.text: DOI: 10.5121 / ijfcst.2014.4102 17Quality control at each stage of production in the textile industry has become a key factor in maintaining its existence in the highly competitive global market. Problems of manual fabric defect inspection are inaccurate and time consuming, with early and accurate fabric defect detection being an important phase of quality control. Computer vision, i.e. automated fabric defect inspection systems, is considered by many researchers from different countries to be very useful in solving these problems. There are two major challenges that need to be solved in order to achieve a successful automated fabric defect inspection system: failure detection and fault classification. In this paper we will discuss various techniques for automated fabric defect classification, then show an overview of classifiers used in automated fabric defect inspection systems, and finally compare these classifiers by using performance indicators.

sections.heading: 1. INTRODUCTION
sections.text: Product quality assurance is considered one of the most important priorities in industrial production, as is the textile industry; the quality of the textile product is seriously affected by defects; failure to detect defects costs time, money and consumer satisfaction; therefore, early and accurate detection of fabric defects is an important phase of quality control; manual inspection is time-consuming and the level of accuracy is insufficient to meet the current demand of the highly competitive international market; therefore, the expected quality cannot be maintained with manual inspection; automated, i.e. computer-aided fabric defect inspection is the solution to the problems caused by manual inspection; the automated fabric defect inspection system has been attracting extensive attention from researchers in many countries for years; the automated fabric defect inspection system mainly involves two challenging problems, namely defect detection and defect inspection.

sections.heading: 2. LITERATURE REVIEW
sections.text: Some efforts were made to examine automated, i.e. computer vision-based inspection systems [1, 2], where not many attempts were made to examine automated, i.e. computer vision-based, textile defect inspection systems [3-6]. All focused on error detection, none of which focused on error classification. Kumar [3] used about 150 references for his comprehensive examination of automated textile defect inspection systems. His investigation was limited exclusively to error detection methods. Likewise, the surveys by Mahajan et al. [4], Ngan et al. [5] and Shanbhag et al. [6] were only focused on error detection techniques. Furthermore, their collection and organization were not good enough.

sections.heading: 3. FABRIC DEFECTS
sections.text: It has been reported in [7] that fabric defects cause about 85% of defects detected in the textile industry. Fabric prices fall by 45% -65% for high-quality second- or third-generation goods [8]. Therefore, it is of great importance that these defects are detected, detected and prevented. There are a large number of fabric defects, including color yarn, missing yarn, missing time and customer satisfaction. Therefore, early and accurate fabric defect detection is a (a) (b) (fabric) (d) (f). Poor fabric detection incurs additional costs in terms of money, time and customer satisfaction. Therefore, early and accurate fabric defect detection is a (b) (fabric) (d) (d) (f).

sections.heading: 4. FABRIC DEFECT INSPECTION PROCESS
sections.text: Developing an automated, i.e. computer vision-based system for substance defect inspection involves several steps, as shown in Figure 2. Each step has an impact on the performance of the subsequent steps. Weak design and implementation of one step complicate the subsequent steps, which leads to a tougher development of the system. Therefore, each step is of great importance in developing a fully automated system for the textile industry. An automated substance inspection system consists of the following steps, as shown in Figure 2. In this work, we mainly focus on only one step of developing a computer vision-based substance defect inspection system. This is the classification stage, as shown in Figure 2. A number of experiments have been undertaken for computer vision-based substance defect inspection [9-31]. Few of them have focused on classification, with the majority focusing on defect detection. Mainly three defect detection techniques [3, 11], namely statistical, spectral and motion-based techniques, have been used.

sections.heading: 5. PERFORMANCE METRICS OF CLASSIFIERS
sections.text: Different indicators can be used to measure the performance of a classifier. Classification accuracy, model complexity and training time are considered the three most important indicators for an automated defect inspection system.

sections.heading: 6. A SURVEY OF CLASSIFIERS
sections.text: Various techniques were used in the classification, including ANNs, support vector machines (SVMs), clustering and statistical conclusions.

sections.heading: 6.1. Statistical Inference
sections.text: Cohen et al. [21] have chosen the statistical test for classification, using the likelihood ratio test as a statistical test to implement a binary classification, i.e. a classification according to only one property, erroneous or error-free. Campbell et al. [22] have used hypotheses tests for classification and introduced a classification according to only faulty or error-free classes.

sections.heading: 6.2. Support Vector Machine
sections.text: Murino et al. [13] used SVMs for classification; they worked on spatial domains; they used characteristics of three types; the characteristics were extracted from grayscale histogram, error form and co-occurrence matrix; the process of feature extraction was considered complex due to some of the characteristics; the basic SVM scheme is designed for the problem of binary classification; they used SVMs to solve the multiclass problem, i.e. a unique defect categorisation; they implemented SVMs with a 1-vs-1 binary decision tree scheme to solve the multiclass problem; two data sets, i.e. image sets were used separately throughout their work; one set contained 11 types of defects; and the other set contained 9 types of defects.

sections.heading: 6.3. Clustering
sections.text: Campbell et al. [20] have used model-based clusters for defect classification. Clustering is not a good choice for real-time systems such as computer-visual goods inspection systems.

sections.heading: 7. COMPARISON OF CLASSIFIERS
sections.text: The articles discussed in the previous section are typical examples of the effort required for computer-aided tissue defect inspection. If we take these articles as an example, we will perform some comparative analyses, as in Fig. 3. A little more effort has been made to solve the multi-class problem, i.e. to clearly categorize defects, than to perform a binary classification, i.e. the classification of only faulty and error-free classes. This is shown in Fig. 3 (a). Fig. 3 (b) shows that ANNs have been selected much more strongly than any other methods for classification.

sections.heading: 8. COMPARATIVE ANALYSIS OF ARTIFICIAL NEURAL NETWORKS
sections.text: From the comparative discussion of the articles in the previous section, we found that ANNs were chosen for classification much more than any other methods. If we take these articles as an example, we will perform another comparative analysis, as in Fig. 4. We see in Fig. 4 that back propagation is the most commonly used learning algorithm when ANNs are used as classifiers. Finally, we compare the performance of ANN models in relation to three performance matrices - accuracy, model complexity and training time, as shown in Table 2.

sections.heading: 9. CONCLUSION
sections.text: This paper first examined the most important defect classification techniques for automated screen defect inspection systems, then the defect classification systems for automated screen defect inspection systems. Finally, we compared these classification systems based on three known performance indicators - accuracy, model complexity, and training time. We hope this paper would be useful for any novice in automated screen defect inspection.
